snippet: I was the bare-minimum student, checking off “to do” boxes, and the plan worked. I didn’t learn much of anything.
abstract: Pamela Paul laments teenage years and young adulthood spent taking few academic risks; says real learning comes from making mistakes and figuring out what went wrong but academic structures do not always support this approach; expresses hope that importance of taking risks and not always doing well may be gaining currency in schools.
lead_paragraph: I was the bare-minimum student, checking off “to do” boxes, and the plan worked. I didn’t learn much of anything.

headline.seo: Brown Alumna Recalls What She Failed to Learn
